Have you ever had to drive in a snow whiteout? Living in the Midwest, let me tell you, sometimes it's scary. One time, at 17, coming home from work at midnight, I drove off the road and ended up in a ditch. There were no cell phones back then. I had to walk, knock on a stranger's door, and beg to use their phone to call a tow truck. Luckily, the guy owned a truck and pulled me out. Nowadays, who's going to answer the door at midnight?  On a few other occasions.. the deer will be running across the road. So you have to swerve to avoid a collision.    #snow #whiteout #snowstorm

Avoid frozen cocktail machines on vacation:  1. It's All Sugar!!! 2. Premixed alcohol can have inconsistent portions; empty bottles on liquor tree, sugar clumps clogs sensors. 3. Top-loading section gets nasty due to sugar; machines require regular cleaning 4. As i guess, Android phones holds these great PROs over iPhones: 1ï¸âƒ£ Customization: Android offers more flexibility to personalize your phone's interface and settings. 2ï¸âƒ£ Affordability: Android phones come in a wide range of prices, making them more accessible to different budgets. 3ï¸âƒ£ Variety: Android offers a wide selection of phone models with different features and designs to choose from.  While, these are a few CONs in my opinion: 1ï¸âƒ£ Fragmentation: Due to the variety of Android devices, software updates may not be available for all phones simultaneously. 2ï¸âƒ£ Security: Some argue that iPhones/iOS have stronger security measures in place compared to Android. 3ï¸âƒ£ Ecosystem Integration: iPhones/iOS provide seamless integration with other Apple devices, which may be lacking with Android. Here's a list of explicit and implicit subsidies for fossil fuels in the United States across federal, state, and local levels:  ### Federal Level 1. **Percentage Depletion Allowance**: Allows oil and gas companies to deduct a fixed percentage of gross revenue from their taxable income. 2. **Domestic Manufacturing Deduction**: Provides a tax deduction for income derived from domestic production activities, including fossil fuel extraction. 3. **Intangible Drilling Costs**: Permits companies to deduct most of the costs associated with drilling new wells immediately. 4. **Master Limited Partnerships (MLPs)**: Allows fossil fuel companies to structure as partnerships, avoiding corporate income taxes. 5. **Strategic Petroleum Reserve**: Federal spending to maintain emergency oil reserves. 6. **Low-cost Leasing of Public Lands**: Offers fossil fuel companies leases on public lands at below-market rates.  ### State Level 1. **Severance Tax Exemptions**: Reductions or exemptions from taxes on the extraction of natural resources. 2. **State Tax Credits**: Includes credits for drilling costs, enhanced recovery projects, and capital expenditures. 3. **Royalty Relief Programs**: Reduces royalties owed to the state for drilling on state lands. 4. **Fuel Tax Exemptions**: Reduces or eliminates state fuel taxes for certain fossil fuel uses.  ### Local Level 1. **Property Tax Breaks**: Reduces property taxes for fossil fuel extraction sites. 2. **Infrastructure Support**: Local government funding for infrastructure improvements that benefit fossil fuel operations. 3. **Reduced Permit Fees**: Lower fees for permits related to fossil fuel exploration and extraction. 4. **Job Creation Incentives**: Local subsidies aimed at attracting fossil fuel companies by offering financial incentives for job creation.  ### Implicit Subsidies 1. **Environmental Externalities**: The societal costs of pollution and environmental degradation not accounted for in fossil fuel prices. 2. **Health Costs**: Public health costs from fossil fuel-related air and water pollution borne by society rather than the industry. 3. **Military Protection**: Government spending on military operations to protect oil supply routes and infrastructure. 4. **Disaster Relief**: Government-funded disaster recovery efforts following fossil fuel-related environmental disasters. 5. **Insurance Subsidies**: Government-backed insurance programs that reduce the risk costs for fossil fuel companies.  These subsidies significantly lower the cost of fossil fuel production and consumption, often masking the true economic and environmental costs.

ğŸ“›ğŸ”¥ Bombay HC grants ad-interim stay in Rs 65 crore demand over reconciliation statement mismatch  â¡ï¸The Bombay High Court has issued an interim stay on a demand order seeking to recover Input Tax Credit (ITC) worth Rs. 65 crores due to unreconciled ITC reported in Table 12F of FORM GSTR-9C by the petitioner.  â¡ï¸ The petitioner argued that the mismatch between ITC reported in Annual GST Returns and Annual Financial Statements occurred because GST paid by Branch Offices and ITC claimed by the Head Office had no financial impact at the entity level.  â¡ï¸ The petitioner claimed that the ITC pertains to intra-company deemed supplies received by the Head Office from its distinct GSTINs (Branch Offices), which were duly reported by the Branch Offices in their monthly returns.  â¡ï¸ The petitioner also disputed the validity of Notification No. 9/2023-Central Tax and Notification No. 56/2023-Central Tax, which extended the time limits for issuing orders under sections 73(9) and 73(10) of the GST Act.  â¡ï¸ The High Court granted ad-interim relief, restraining the Revenue Department from initiating recovery action until September 30, 2024.  âœ”ï¸ Bombay HC - FIS Payment Solutions And Services India Pvt Ltd. The selection process for implementing Large Language Models (LLMs) within an organization for specific use cases involves several critical steps, each designed to ensure that the chosen LLM aligns with organizational goals, operational needs, and budget constraints.   Here's a detailed guide based on the latest insights and practices:  1.  Define Your Use Case and Requirements:     -  Start by defining the problem or task the LLM is meant to solve or enhance.   This could range from customer support, content generation, data analysis, to internal knowledge management.  Understanding the specific needs helps in narrowing down the type of LLM required.  2.  Identify Key Capabilities Needed:     -  Determine if you need capabilities like natural language understanding, generation, translation, or specific domain knowledge (e.g., legal, medical).   Consider whether the model needs to be fine-tuned for your industry or if general-purpose capabilities suffice.  3.  Shortlist LLMs Based on Requirements:     -  Model Size and Performance:  Larger models might offer better performance but at higher computational costs.   Consider if your task requires the depth of understanding provided by models like Cohere, GPT-4, Gemani or if a smaller, more specialized model like BERT for sentiment analysis would do.     -  Training Data:   Look for models trained on datasets relevant to your use case.   For instance, if dealing with medical texts, a model with medical training would be preferable.     -  Cost: Evaluate the cost implications, considering not just the direct costs (like API fees) but also infrastructure for deployment, maintenance, and potential fine-tuning.  4.  Evaluate on Specific Criteria:     -  Performance:   Test shortlisted models with your data or similar datasets to see how they perform in terms of accuracy, latency, and relevance.     -  Integration: Check how easily the LLM can be integrated with your existing systems.   This includes API availability, compatibility with your tech stack, and security considerations.     -  Scalability and Maintenance:  Consider future scalability. Will the model's performance degrade with increased load?   What are the ongoing maintenance requirements?  5.  Prototyping and Testing:     -  Before full-scale deployment, prototype with the most promising candidates.   This phase should involve real-world testing, possibly in a controlled environment, to see how the model interacts with actual data and user queries.  6.  Selection and Deployment:     -  After testing, choose the LLM that best balances performance, cost, and integration ease.   Plan the deployment, considering factors like data privacy, especially if dealing with sensitive information.  7.  Fine-Tuning, Monitoring, and Maintenance:     -  Post-deployment, fine-tuning might be necessary to adapt the LLM to your specific needs or to improve performance based on feedback.   Establish processes for continuous monitoring for biases, performance degradation, or updates in model capabilities.  8.  Stay Informed:     -  The field of LLMs is rapidly evolving.   Regularly review new models, updates, and trends in AI, like the shift towards more efficient models or the integration of LLMs with other AI technologies for enhanced capabilities.  This process ensures that the organization leverages the power of LLMs efficiently, tailored to its unique needs, thereby enhancing productivity, reducing costs, or improving customer interaction, among other benefits.   Remember, the choice of an LLM should be strategic, aligning with both immediate needs and long-term organizational goals.

1. **Federalism and Autonomy**: There's a growing tension regarding federalism, where states like Tamil Nadu argue for more autonomy. This includes issues over taxation, borrowing limits, and the implementation of central policies like GST, NEET, and the National Education Policy (NEP) without adequate consultation with state governments. The central government's approach to these matters has been seen by some in Tamil Nadu as undermining state rights, leading to conflicts over how resources are allocated and how policies are implemented.  2. **Cultural and Political Identity**: Tamil Nadu has a strong regional identity, often expressed through language, culture, and political movements that emphasize Dravidian identity over a broader Indian nationalism. This has sometimes led to conflicts with central policies perceived as promoting a more uniform national identity, like the push for Hindi or certain cultural practices, which are seen as encroaching on Tamil culture.  3. **Economic Policies and Resource Allocation**: There's a sentiment that Tamil Nadu contributes significantly more to the central pool than it receives back in terms of central transfers. This disparity in economic treatment, where states like Tamil Nadu argue they are taxed more but receive less in return, fuels resentment. The central government's economic policies, including how funds are distributed, have been criticized for not adequately considering the contributions of prosperous states like Tamil Nadu.  4. **Political Confrontations**: Incidents like the withdrawal of general consent to the CBI by the Tamil Nadu government, or the refusal to play the national anthem in the state assembly, have been interpreted as symbolic acts of defiance against central authority. These actions, along with the central government's reactions, contribute to the narrative of an adversarial relationship.  5. **Governance and Policy Implementation**: The central government's decisions on various issues, from education (NEET) to taxation (GST), have been implemented in ways that Tamil Nadu's government has found restrictive or contrary to state interests. This includes the central government's stance on state bills, like those related to education, which have been delayed or returned by the Governor, seen as an extension of central control.  The situation is complex, involving economic, cultural, and political dimensions. While there's clear friction, much of it stems from differing visions of federalism, economic policies, and cultural identity, rather than a straightforward antagonism. However, these issues are often framed in a binary opposition in public discourse, which might not fully capture the nuanced interactions between state and central governance in India.

With such moves aimed at facilitating international transactions, investing internationally has become more accessible.  During the course of this #MarcellusWebinar, our Global Compounders Fund Management team have discussed:  a. How investing Globally has become easier b. The advantages that a Resident Indian now benefits from c. The importance and advantages of diversification especially with the Indian and US Equity markets having a low correlation d. How a 50:50 Indian and American portfolio could have generated a higher return over a 20-Year period and more.  With GCP also outperforming the benchmark since inception by ~8%, we also answer the much-asked question on how the Portfolio is placed going forward.  Watch the entire webinar to learn more. https://shorturl.at/7BPhe

Let me explain with an example.   Digital gold - Buy today for Rs.500, u effectively get gold worth Rs.485 since 3% GST is upfront deducted.   Let's assume gold price has appreciated by 10% in a year and investor sells - on all digital gold platforms the sell price is 2-3% lower than buy price. So the user gets back Rs.522 net.   Instead of getting 550-500 = Rs.50, the user gets Rs.22 profit and lost Rs.28 in charges.   Take the same example with Gold MF where the TER is 0.5% & GST is zero. So for the same 10% growth net of TER the invested value appreciates to Rs.547.5 and hence Rs.47.5 profit.  Which product is right for the investor?

Why is the US not winning the Drone War with China despite all the sanctions and tech blockade on China's drone industry and massive subsidies for local manufacturing.  US-made drones are significantly more expensive and less capable than their Chinese counterparts, which poses challenges for their adoption and competitiveness:  1. US drones are priced three to four times higher than Chinese models, despite not offering superior technology[4].  2. Many commercial UAVs from the US cost tens of thousands of dollars more than comparable Chinese drones, which is a no-no for industries such as big scale commercial farming where drones are used at scale[5].  3. The high costs of US drones make them less feasible for budget-constrained users like Ukraine's military, commercial videographers, or even YouTube content creators [5].  Key factors contributing to the higher costs of US drones include:  - Labor costs - Lack of skilled labour  - Smaller production scale - Expensive custom chipsets - Stringent US Defense Department requirements - Prohibition on using Chinese components[4][5]  In contrast, Chinese drones, particularly those made by DJI, are very high quality as proven by the Ukraine War [5], much more affordable, easily repaired or replaced; and dominate the market:  - DJI alone controls about 70-80% of the global commercial and US drone markets[4]. - Chinese drones remain popular among  US law enforcement agencies, forestry departments and survey and inspection departments of various arms of government due to their lower costs and high functionality and reliability [4]. - Even US allies are dependent on Chinese drones and components as they are the only supplier for many key components such as rotors, controllers, sensors, batteries, etc.  The significant price disparity makes it challenging for US manufacturers to compete, especially against Chinese companies[4]. This cost difference is a major factor driving the continued popularity and widespread use of Chinese-made drones, even in sensitive sectors.  Citations: [1] AUKUS AI drones shadowed by China's tech supremacy - Asia Times https://asiatimes.com/2024/08/aukus-ai-drones-shadowed-by-chinas-tech-supremacy/ [2] Can U.S. drone makers compete with cheap, high-quality Chinese drones? https://teddit.net/r/technology/comments/17ehn1c/can_us_drone_makers_compete_with_cheap/ [3] Can U.S. drone makers compete with cheap, high-quality Chinese drones? https://www.cnbc.com/2023/10/11/can-us-drone-makers-compete-with-cheap-high-quality-chinese-drones.html [4] Chinese UAVs 'Hover' Over The US Despite Federal Block; Cheap DJI ... https://www.eurasiantimes.com/chinese-uavs-hover-over-the-us-despite-federal/ [5] Chinese UAVs 'Outperform' US Drones In Ukraine War; WSJ Report ... https://www.eurasiantimes.com/chinese-uavs-outperform-us-drones-in-ukraine-war/

The steps taken by the Government to curb the ITC frauds in GST: 1. Insertion of sub-rule (4A) in rule 8 of CGST Rules, 2017 to provide for risk based biometric-based Aadhaar authentication of registration applicants who appear to be risky based on data analytics  2. Amendment in rule 9 of CGST Rules, 2017 to provide for physical verification in high-risk cases, even when Aadhaar has been authenticated  3. Amendment in rule 10A of CGST Rules, 2017 to provide for requirement of bank account furnished as a part of registration process to be in the name of the registered person and obtained on PAN of the registered person and also linked with Aadhaar in case of proprietorship firm and that the details of bank account will be required to be furnished within 30 days of grant of registration or before filing of GSTR-1, whichever is earlier  4. Restriction on availment of ITC to invoices and debit notes furnished by the supplier in their statement of outward supplies  5. Filing of FORM GSTR-1 made mandatory before filing of FORM GSTR-3B for a tax period and filing of FORM GSTR-1 made mandatorily sequential  6. Making the beneficial owner liable for penal action and prosecution similar to that of actual supplier/recipient, in cases where a supply has been made without the issuance of an invoice, or invoice has been issued without supply, or excess ITC has been availed/distributed  7. Amendment in Section 83 of the CGST Act to provide that provisional attachment of property can be done in respect of any other person who has retained benefits of such transactions  8. Restriction on generation of e-way bills by non- compliant taxpayers  9. Reduction in threshold limit for issue of e-invoice for B2B transactions from Rs. 10 Crore to Rs. 5 Crore w.e.f. 01.08.2023  10. Regular use of data analytics to identify or track risky GST registrations to detect tax evasion.  11. All India drive to weed out fake/bogus registrations 12. Sharing of data amongst enforcement agencies for targeted interventions on continuing basis.

INTERESTING RULING IN GST. â© Maharashtra advance ruling authority held that various other charges collected by the builders from buyers will not be considered part of main construction service hence will be taxed as independent services at the rates prescribed under related classification code. On basis of this ruling, builder charged 18% GST on other services and 12% GST on construction services.  â© Aggrieved by the order of AAR, builder filed appeal before advance ruling appellate authority who partially modified AAR's ruling holding that those services which are directly linked with construction will be taxed as composite supply wherein construction services are principal supply hence to be taxed @ 12% while other services will be taxed as per AAR's ruling. Appellate authority also directed the builder to refund excess GST (6%) charged on those services which are linked with construction and than claim refund from department. Builder is not allowed to first claim refund of excess tax collected & deposited. and than refund to customers. Here is order copy https://www.mahagst.gov.in/sites/default/files/Ms%20Puranik%20Builders%20Limited%2C%20Maharashtra%20AAAR%20for%20rectification%20of%20Advance%20Ruling%20bearing%20Order%20No.%20MAH_AAAR_DS-RM_19_2022-23%20dated%2030.03.2023..pdf

ğŸ“¢ HC: Directs to release seized vehicle and goods Kumar Cargo Solution Vs. State of UP & Ors. WRIT TAX No. - 1200 of 2024  Facts of the Case â–ªThe Assessee, Kumar Cargo Solution, had its vehicle and goods seized by the authorities on the grounds of an alleged intention to evade tax. â–ªThe authorities penalized the Assessee despite the physical invoice matching entirely with the E-invoice. The Assessee explained that the discrepancy was due to a bona fide mistake and brought this to the attention of the seizing authority. â–ªThe Assessee filed a writ petition challenging the seizure and penalty imposed by the authorities.  Court Judgement Observations: â–ªThe Allahabad High Court noted that the authorities' view of an "intention to evade tax" was not supported by the facts of the case. â–ªThe Court emphasized that without any intention or mens rea to evade tax, no penalty can be imposed.  Judgment: â–ªThe Allahabad High Court directed the release of the seized vehicle and goods. â–ªThe Court disposed of the writ petition, ruling in favor ofÂ theÂ Assessee.

ğŸ”¥ğŸ“› AAR: Leasing of land by Maha Metro for construction of commercial space attracts 18% GST  â¡ï¸ Maharashtra AAR ruled that leasing land by Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation (MMRC) for constructing a commercial bare shell structure at Nagpur Airport Metro Station is taxable under GST.  â¡ï¸ The leased land, meant for commercial use, does not qualify for exemption under entry 41 of Notification No. 12/2017-Central Tax (Rate).  â¡ï¸ MMRC received an upfront lease payment of â‚¹10.26 crores, on which 18% GST is applicable.  â¡ï¸ The AAR emphasized that exemptions should be construed strictly, noting the land was originally allotted for commercial purposes.  â¡ï¸ Citing legal precedents, AAR concluded that renting immovable property is taxable under GST, and the GST demand is valid in this case.  âœ”ï¸ Maharashtra AAR - In the matter of Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Ltd. ğŸ”¥ğŸ“› HC: Quashes order levying GST on full value of HAM contract; Remands matter  â¡ï¸ Madras High Court set aside tax orders demanding â‚¹176.66 Crores for GST under the Hybrid Annuity Model (HAM) for road construction and operation.  â¡ï¸ The contract involved 40% payment during project execution in 5 installments, with the remaining 60% paid annually over 14 years.  â¡ï¸ The Court held that GST cannot be levied on the entire project value if no invoice is raised by the contractor, contradicting the Department's view.  â¡ï¸ The Court directed re-examination of the case in light of a CBIC Circular clarifying time of supply for such projects.  â¡ï¸ The Court clarified that advance completion and payment in annuities do not affect input tax credit entitlement or imply immediate GST liability.  âœ”ï¸ Madras HC - K N R Srirangam Infra Pvt Ltd. ğŸ”¥ğŸ“› Order passed during pendency of IRP proceedings was not sustainable and to be set aside: HC  â¡ï¸ The petitioner was undergoing resolution proceedings before an Interim Resolution Professional (IRP) when a tax determination case was initiated.  â¡ï¸ The petitioner informed the adjudicating authority about the ongoing IRP process and requested time to seek permission to contest the proceedings.  â¡ï¸ Despite this, no further notice was issued or dates fixed for the adjudication proceedings.  â¡ï¸ The adjudicating authority proceeded to pass an order under section 73 of the UPGST Act without considering the pending IRP process.  â¡ï¸ The court held that the impugned order was invalid and should be set aside since it was passed during the pendency of the Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP).  âœ”ï¸ Allahabad HC - Bgr Energy Systems Ltd. v. ğŸ”¥ğŸ“› ITC available in ledger under AP VAT regime could be transferred to AP GST regime as it was not tax paid in excess: HC  â¡ï¸ Upon the introduction of the GST Act, input tax credit from the AP VAT Act was transferred to the assessee-dealers' ledgers under the AP GST Act.  â¡ï¸ An audit objection later claimed that tax credit during the bifurcation of the state could not be transferred as Section 56 of the Andhra Pradesh Reorganisation Act, 2014 only allowed a refund.  â¡ï¸ Based on this objection, authorities reversed the transferred credit and raised a demand.  â¡ï¸ Section 56 concerns refunds of taxes collected in excess, but the input tax credit in question is not an excess tax payment.  â¡ï¸ Therefore, the court held that Section 56 does not apply and allowed the writ petitions, setting aside the demand orders.  âœ”ï¸ Andhra Pradesh HC - Sri Lakshmi Vallabha Granites v. *Believe it or not*â€”the government has once again proven its knack for making education a luxury by taxing research! IIT Delhi, a premier institute known for contributing to India's intellectual capital, has received a hefty â‚¹120 crore GST bill for research funding from 2017 to 2022. And who do we have to thank for this academic heist? None other than the finance ministry led by our dear Nirmala Sitharaman.  Remember when the same FM once stood on a podium and declared that she wished she could bring down taxes to nil.  Well, surprise! It seems that promise was as flimsy as a politician's campaign slogan.   After all, why invest in the nation's brainpower when you can squeeze every last penny out of it? It's almost poeticâ€”cripple the universities with high tuition fees, then slap them with a GST bill for daring to conduct research.  But the madness doesn't stop there. In the recent budget, the import tax on chemicals used in higher secondary labs was increased, making sure even basic science education feels the pinch.   So, let's get this straight: research and education are prime targets for revenue, but what about cracking down on money laundering, tax evasion, and the loopholes that the rich and powerful so gleefully exploit?   Oh no, that would require real effort from the revenue department, wouldn't it?  It's funny how the government always manages to tax the common man, the students, and the educational institutions trying to better this country while letting the big fish swim free.   So, hats off to the FM and her teamâ€”this is peak governance! Because nothing screams "nation-building" like taxing the very foundation of knowledge and innovation.  #education @nsitharaman @FinMinIndia @EduMinOfIndia

This move by the Modi government to slap IIT Delhi with a â‚¹120 crore GST on research grants from 2017 to 2022 is nothing short of an attack on scientific progress and intellectual growth. Taxing research, which is the backbone of innovation and technological advancement, reveals this government's complete disregard for the future of India's academic and research institutions. Instead of empowering institutions like IIT Delhi to excel in research, they are burdening them with punitive taxes.  On the other hand, the same Modi government conveniently exempts Patanjali's research from taxes for five years, from 2022 to 2027. The hypocrisy is blatant. When it comes to aiding corporate allies and their dubious ventures, the government is quick to roll out tax exemptions. But when it comes to institutions driving the nation's scientific and technological development, the same government isn't hesitant to cripple them with hefty taxes.  This is not governance for the peopleâ€”this is governance for political cronies. By taxing research while exempting corporate entities like Patanjali, the Modi government is sending a clear message: corporate interests come first, and the nation's intellectual future comes last.

One frequently asked question I get is how to divide budget between search and display on Amazon  Where there is no one size fit all answer to this, here is what I usually follow  a) When you start, allocate almost 100% to search. Find keywords which are highly relevant to your product. While they are still generic, they are also specific enough to what you are selling. Eg: "ceiling fan" is a generic keyword, but"remote controlled ceiling fan" is a specific generic keyword. In the beginning, allocate almost 100% budget to these specific generic keywords. Once you exhaust, start testing the pure generic keywords  b) Once you reach a certain scale with search, start experimenting with display. But do targeted display. You can target your brand viewers, category viewers etc. Display usually have a much lower CPC, but also poorer conversions. So take calls basis the CPC*Conversion rate metric.  So if your search CPC is Rs 20 and conversion of x and your display CPC is Rs 5 and conversion is x/3, you are better off increasing spends on display  c) Once you are amongst the top 3-4 players in the category, your search and display split has to mimic the consumer behavior in the category. And Amazon Pi gives you all the details here. Go to Audience Planning Insights. Check the audience size in the selected subcategory( Level 2). You can get the size for both searchers( people who arrive at a product by searching) and browsers( People who browse through category banners and filters to arrive at product). If there are 2M searchers and 1 M browsers, then your search to display ratio also should be 2:1 unless of course you see a drastic difference in your CPC and conversion rates between Search and Display  Once the broad allocation is done, then you can keep optimizing and making changes dynamically.   Sometimes CPCs in search gets crazy high due to irrational spending and bidding. In those months, better to increase allocation in display to maintain overall ACOS

Lets talk about #NPS ğğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ ğğğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ ğ’ğœğ¡ğğ¦ğ. My take : #Invest in NPS if you are in taxable slab. ğ—ªğ—µğ˜†: Consider you are in 30% tax slab and your income is 20lacs. If you invest 1lac in NPS you are saving 30k tax. Now see the magic. Your investment value 1lac on day 1 with 70k investment(if you remove the tax savings). And additionally you will get returns on these investments, on conservative case also you will get 8%.  Few #important things are here to consider 1. Long waiting period to enjoy the benefits. 2. Don't invest over amounts in NPS. Only invest amount which are satisfying the limits for tax saving. a. In Old tax regime you can invest upto 2lacs(1.5lac 80c and 50k 80CCD) and 10% of your basic pay if you are eligible for corporate NPS account. b. In new tax regime you can invest upto 10%(Increased to 14% in recent budget) of your basic salary.  Only invest in NPS if you can hold on till that much long periods, consider it like another PF only.  I'm not a registered advisor, its just my opinion.  #investing #stockmarket #tiwk

Summary: Time Limits and Conditions for Issuing Notice u/s 148 of the Income Tax Act General Time Limit:  â—¾A notice under Section 148 can be issued within 4 years from the end of the relevant assessment year if income has escaped assessment.  Extended Time Limit for Larger Amounts:  â—¾If the income escaping assessment is â‚¹1,00,000 or more, the notice can be issued within 6 years from the end of the relevant assessment year.  Income Related to Foreign Assets:  â—¾In cases where income related to any asset (including financial interest) located outside India has escaped assessment, the notice can be issued within 16 years from the end of the relevant assessment year.  â—¾These time limits are essential for determining the validity of any notice issued under Section 148 of theÂ IncomeÂ TaxÂ Act.

The rich pay most of the taxes contrary to what most think.   But percentage isn't even a good metric as the rich may most of the money off capital gains, which is taxed differently, and many of the rich don't have income (like Steve Jobs famously paying himself $1 a year).  So we should talk absolute amount paid in.

When people say the rich don't pay taxes it is disinformation as the rich pay most of the taxes.    And comparing percentages is like apples to oranges because wealth can be earned tons of different ways than just income, and all ways are taxed at different rates.  Therefore, we need to talk absolute numbers, not percentages.

How much tax government gets, in simple words explained  Earn 48 lacs as professional income (suppose you're an architect) by raising an invoice. Government will get 8.5 lacs GST. Now pay income tax on 48 @ 30 pc & SC say 15 Lacs. You're left with 33 Lacs. Now buy an SUV for 26 lacs. It attracts GST of 28 pc. Another 7 lacs gone and total cost of car is 33 lacs. You're left with an egg.  Government gets 8.5 plus 15 plus 7 lacs ie 30.5 lacs. Hence to buy a car of 26 lacs from your earning, government gets 30.5 lacs and you're left with nothing if you earned 48 Lacs

There is no GST currently on Rakhi.  While 2012, the Value Added Tax (VAT) on Rakhi in India was generally levied at the rate applicable to "unclassified goods," which varied by state. Most states had a VAT rate of around 5% to 12.5% for unclassified goods, but it could differ slightly depending on the specific state's tax regulations. For example, in Maharashtra, the VAT on Rakhi was 5%   Also in 2012, the Value Added Tax (VAT) on sweets in India varied by state. Generally, sweets were subject to a VAT rate of around 5% to 14.5%, depending on the state. Maharashtra: 5% Delhi: 5% Karnataka: 5% Tamil Nadu: 12.5% Uttar Pradesh: 12.5%

Peter Schiff Has A Warning On Fed Cutting Interest Rate: Federal Budget Deficits And Weaker Dollar Will Fuel Higher Inflation  Prominent economist and vocal Bitcoin BTC/USD critic Peter Schiff cautioned that a combination of lower interest rates and a recession could lead to a surge in inflation. This, he believes, could be triggered by increased federal deficits and a weaker dollar.  What Happened: On Tuesday, Schiff took to X to express his concerns about the potential consequences of a recession and lower interest rates.  He stated, "The irony is that investors believe lower #inflation and a #recession will allow the #Fed to cut interest rates. However, the effect of lower interest rates and a recession will be larger federal budget deficits and a weaker dollar, both of which will lead to higher inflation."  Why It Matters: Schiff's warning comes at a time when the Federal Reserve's monetary policy is under intense scrutiny. The July Consumer Price Index inflation report, scheduled for release on Wednesday, could significantly influence investor expectations ahead of the Fed's September meeting.  Depending on the inflation data, markets may gain clarity on whether to expect a modest or substantial interest rate cut next month. If inflation slows more than anticipated, it would reinforce the view that inflation is nearing the Fed's 2% target, potentially pushing traders to bet on a larger rate cut by 50 basis points in September.  Conversely, if inflation meets or exceeds expectations, it could signal a setback in the disinflationary trend, increasing the likelihood of a more modest 0.25% rate cut.  Additionally, the Producer Price Index for July showed a decline following an unexpected rise in June, much to the relief of the markets. Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer for Independent Advisor Alliance, noted that the lower-than-expected PPI data is good news for those worried about the Fed being cautious in lowering interest rates due to lingering inflation. Traders are now looking to retail sales for signals on consumer spending as they anticipate the release of July's CPI.  Moreover, Mohamed El-Erian, Chief Economic Advisor at Allianz, criticized the Federal Reserve for not reducing interest rates in July and warned that the market's anticipation of a 200 basis point cut in the next year is excessive. El-Erian voiced his concerns about the lack of clarity regarding future rate cuts, adding to the market uncertainty.  Jason Furman, former Chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, dismissed fears of an imminent U.S. recession but urged the Federal Reserve to act decisively if unemployment rises. Furman emphasized that emergency rate cuts are not required at the moment, suggesting that inflation is only slightly above where it should be.

The total budget for the Rooppur Nuclear Power Plant project is $12 billion. Out of this, Russia is providing 90% of the funding, and the Bangladesh government is covering 10%. The entire project is being managed by Russia's Rosatom. Bangladesh's 10% share, which amounts to $1.2 billion, is being paid annually in installments. For instance, because Bangladesh did not pay this year's installment on time, a penalty of $160,000 was imposed on Bangladesh. However, the Russian contractor eventually waived the penalty (Source: May 19, 2024, Prothom Alo).  Now, please explain to me how $5 billion could be stolen by Sheikh Hasina or anyone else in Bangladesh when Russia is funding 90% of the project, and we are only paying 10% in yearly installments. ğŸ“¢HC: No prohibition on filing returns on another State's GST portal where Bank's branch 'exists' Standard Chartered Bank vs. The Principal Commissioner of Central Tax & Ors. WRIT PETITION No.648 of 2024  Facts of the Case â–ªThe case revolved around Standard Chartered Bank, which is registered in Maharashtra, encountering a technical glitch on the Maharashtra GST portal while attempting to file its returns. â–ªDue to the technical issue, the Bank filed its returns on the GST portal of Telangana, where one of its branches exists. The Bank subsequently took credit through TRAN-01 and transferred it to the Maharashtra portal on the same day. â–ªThe Additional Commissioner of Customs and Central Tax assumed that the Bank could not have filed its return on the Telangana portal, leading to a Show Cause Notice (SCN) and an order disallowing the carry forward credit of eligible duties.  Court Judgement â–ª Observations: The Telangana High Court found that there was no legal prohibition under Section 140 of the CGST Act that prevented the Bank from filing its return on the Telangana GST portal, where it had a branch. â–ªThe Court highlighted that the credit was transferred to the Maharashtra portal on the same day with the same PAN, and the Department cannot penalize the Bank due to the technical glitch on the Maharashtra portal. â–ª Judgment: The Court quashed the SCN and the order disallowing the carry forward of credit, ruling in favour of the Bank. The Court held that the Department's actions were "bad in law" and that the Bank's actions were within legal bounds given the circumstances. The writ petition filed by the BankÂ wasÂ allowed.

Sovereign Gold Bonds (SGBs): Is Expiry Near?  1. Government hasn't issued any new SGBs this year.  2. In the 2024-25 budget:    - Gold import duty was cut from 15% to 6%.    - LTCG holding period for gold cut from 36 to 24 months; tax rate reduced from 20% to 12.5%.    - Capital gains tax on gold ETFs: 12.5% for listed and 20% for unlisted funds, starting April 2026.  3. Since 2015, SGBs have raised Rs 72,275 crore by mobilizing 147 tonnes of gold, with nearly 11% annual returns and 2.5-2.75% taxable interest.  4. The government paid over 11% on eight-year SGBs but can now borrow at under 7%. Rising gold prices make SGBs a costly borrowing option.  5. SGBs offer capital gains tax exemption if held till redemption, making them highly attractive to investors.  6. Geopolitical issues and high deficits are driving up gold prices, making cheap borrowing through SGBs difficult.  7. Despite urging citizens to avoid gold, the RBI buys 40 tonnes annually, revealing policy contradictions.  8. The Finance Ministry's recent actions hint at a reevaluation of SGBs, which might be taxed like gold ETFs and mutual funds if reintroduced.

The State Railway of Thailand (SRT) now offers a budget-friendly motorcycle transport service, ensuring swift delivery to the destination station within 1 to 3 days. Customers can choose to send the motorcycle separately or travel with it. The process is straightforward, requiring just four steps:  1. **Submit Documents**    - Take your motorcycle to the station's parcel service area and submit the necessary documents:      - Registration book or a copy of the vehicle's registration (If you are not the owner, provide the owner's identification.)      - Your ID card      - Contact details of the recipient, including name, phone number, address, and destination station  2. **Service Fee Calculation**    - The staff will calculate the service fee, including a handling charge and the transport cost.   3. **Wrap the Motorcycle**    - Protect your motorcycle by wrapping it securely with bubble wrap to prevent damage during transport. You can either do this yourself or ask the staff for assistance.  4. **Collect the Motorcycle**    - Upon arrival at the destination station, if you traveled with the motorcycle, present the "Motorcycle Receipt" provided at the origin station to collect your vehicle. If someone else is collecting it, they must be the designated recipient and present the receipt, which can be shown as a photograph. The station offers motorcycle storage for up to two days if immediate collection is not possible.  For more information, contact the SRT Customer Service Center at 1690, available 24/7, or visit the State Railway of Thailand's official Facebook page.  Source: @PR_SRT

Auto giant Hero MotoCorp has received a demand notice of INR 17.64 Cr from Delhi GST authorities due to disallowed input tax credit for FY 2019-20 ğŸ‘‡   In a regulatory filing, the company said it received the order on Saturday (August 17), which demands a GST of INR 9,38,66,513 ( INR 9.4 Cr), which will be marked up with an interest charge of INR 7.3 Cr, and a penalty of INR 93.86 Lakh, bringing the total up to INR 17.64 Cr.  Further, Hero MotoCorp clarified in the filing that the input tax credit disallowed by the office of the GST officer, New Delhi, was rightfully claimed by it as per the provisions of the GST law but disallowed on account of supplier's non-compliance, which is not attributable to the company. GST Credit Ledger Balance to be shown on debit side in books = Balance of ledger on Portal after filing March 3B Return  GST Cash Ledger Balance to be shown on debit side in books = Balance of ledger on Portal as on 31.03.2024  GST Payable to be shown on credit side in books = Net tax payable in March 3B Return  Rest difference balance of books & Portal = actual difference to be paid or ITC to be recovered which is not in 2A/2B.

ğ—£ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ—±'ğ˜€ ğ—¨-ğ—§ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—»: ğ—”ğ—°ğ—°ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—™ğ—šğ—¦ ğ—•ğ˜‚ğ—±ğ—´ğ—²ğ˜ ğ—¦ğ˜‚ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ—¦ğ—½ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ˜€ ğ——ğ—²ğ—¯ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²  Puntland, after a prolonged standoff, has recently accepted a budget support transfer of over $6 million from the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS). This funding, part of a broader donor-supported initiative, comes through a formula that has been a point of contention between Puntland and the FGS for years.  Historically, Puntland has rejected these budget support funds, arguing that the allocation formula agreed upon by the FGS and other Federal Member States (FMS) is fundamentally unfair. This stance led to the suspension of various development projects in Puntland, as the region sought direct support that bypassed the FGS mechanisms. Puntland's refusal to engage with the intergovernmental processes and its outright rejection of the budget allocation formula created a significant impasse, affecting not only budget support but also the broader intergovernmental relations.  ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ—”ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—™ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—ºğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—®  The current formula used for distributing donor budget support between the FMS, after the FGS takes its 60% share, allocates the remaining 40% among the states as follows::  1. Equal Share- 57% of the total budget support is divided equally among all the FMS. This is meant to ensure a base level of support to each state, regardless of their economic performance or governance.  2. Revenue Enhancement (Performance-Based) - 15% of the support is allocated based on each state's efforts to enhance its revenue collection. This performance-based component rewards states that have taken significant steps to improve their financial self-sufficiency.  3. Expenditure Management (Performance-Based) - Another 15% is distributed based on the effectiveness of each state's expenditure management. This incentivizes efficient and transparent use of funds.  4. Audit & Reporting (Performance-Based) - 10% of the support is tied to the state's audit and reporting standards. States that maintain rigorous financial oversight and transparency are rewarded under this criterion.  5. Fiscal Gap Equalization - The remaining 3% is allocated to address disparities in fiscal capacity among the states, helping to equalize opportunities for development.  While other FMS agreed to this formula, Puntland has consistently argued that it disadvantages the region, leading to its previous refusals.  A suprising Turn of Events  In a surprising move, Puntland recently requested the transfer of budget support funds according to the very formula it had long rejected. This U-turn has sparked widespread debate within and beyond the state. Observers are questioning whether this acceptance signals a shift in Puntland's broader policy stance, and whether this might open the door for the resumption of other development projects that have been on hold.  The decision raises critical questions: Has the Puntland administration now accepted the allocation formula it previously deemed unjust? If so, will this lead to a broader thawing of relations with the FGS, allowing other suspended development projects to move forward in the region?  The implications of this development are significant, leaving many confused about what stances are truly representative of Puntland's official position and what may be driven by personal agendas. The debate over the allocation formula has been a major issue, overshadowing the discussions on the suspended projects. This formula is not just a financial mechanism but a cornerstone for resource sharing between the central government and the FMS, making it a critical point of contention.  Opposition leaders argue that the dispute between the FGS and FMS is more about personal interests than state principles. They suggest that the Puntland president's acceptance of the transfer indicates that personal motivations, rather than a consistent state policy, may be influencing these decisions. #Puntland #Somalia

PUNTLAND CONFIRMS RECEIPT OF WORLD BANK BUDGET SUPPORT FUNDS BUT DENIES IT WAS DEPOSITED IN PRESIDENT DENI'S PERSONAL BANK ACCOUNT   In a long accusatory press conference earlier today against Villa Somalia and MP A. Xaange, Puntland Minister of Information Mr. Mohamoud Aydid Dirir responded to yesterday's Facebook post by Somalia's Deputy Minister of Finance Mr. Abdiqafar Xaange @A_Haange, in which the Deputy Minister listed over $6 million USD in budgetary support the Federal Government transfered to Puntland Treasury.   The FGS Deputy Finance Minister, who is also an MP representing the Mudug region of Puntland, accused President Deni of accepting Budget Support funds, in cash, from the Federal Government of Somalia while blocking millions of dollars of Puntland development funds.  Minister Aydid responding to Minister Xaange confirmed that Puntland did indeed receive $6 million budget support from the World Bank. "Puntland had rights to these funds and following the proper procedures, Puntland submitted required documents and requested the budgetary support funds from the World Bank be transferred to a designated Puntland Ministry of Finance bank account."  Minister Aydid Dirir added that @TheVillaSomalia tried to block these funds, but the World Bank intervened and ordered that funds be immediately transferred to the designated beneficiary, the Puntland State of Somalia.   On the rumor of funds being transferred directly to a designated personal account of President @HESaidADeni, Minister Aydid called it baseless, and added, "World Bank funds can't be transferred to a personal bank account."  Other than the World Bank budget support, Minister Aided also repeatedly denied receiving $6 million directly from the Federal Government.   On the issue of the Office of President Deni few days ago requiring all humanitarian and development projects and programs (https://x.com/radiodaljir/status/1825249302853329405?t=Chv8S-yOxtFT4ihYfoJaHQ&s=19) go through the Office of the President, Radio Daljir asked the Minister if the intention behind this requirement, as accused of the Office by some Puntland contractors, is to deny certain contractors deemed "politically undesirable" from implementing development and humanitarian projects and programs in Puntland.   Minister Dirir denied these accusations and said Puntland has the proper procedures and agencies in place to manage humanitarian and development projects and there are no contract brokers at the Office of the President who seeks monetary gains from such projects and programs.  > Daljir Media

With McDonald's Japan releasing an AI ad, it got me thinking about a couple of things:  1. By reallocating the budget saved from production, companies can increase their media spend, leading to more frequent or widespread ad placements.  2. We bring to the attention of TN CM Thiru @mkstalin the following: Chennai, Tiruchirappalli, Madurai, Palakkad, Salem, and Thiruvananthapuram - these are divisions under Southern Railway; not every division falls under TN.   The budget for doubling works for Southern Railways could be reduced, but the TN-specific projects for doubling works have received an increased allocation of â‚¹1696 Crore in the revised project. The interim budget allocation for TN-specific projects for doubling works was â‚¹1437 Crores. There is an increase in allocation of â‚¹259 Crores.   Notably, the budget for gauge conversion has seen a net increase of 65 Crores for TN-specific projects under Southern Railways. Tiruchchirappalli-Nagore-Karaikal gauge conversion work in TN has received an increased allocation of â‚¹135 Crore.   The overall budget for Southern Railways for Track Renewals (which includes track repair, replacement, and maintenance works) has increased to â‚¹1755 Crores from â‚¹1240 Crores. Most of these Track Renewal projects are allocated to divisions under Southern Railways in Tamil Nadu, ensuring the safety and reliability of our railway network.    While the budgeting for New Lines has been reduced for divisions in TN under Southern Railway, there has been a substantial increase in allocation for Doubling works, Gauge Conversion, and Track Renewals.   However, we seek the following clarification from TN CM Thiru @mkstalin:   - For the Madurai-Tuticorin via Aruppukkottai (143.5 km) New Line, approximately 870.98 Ha. of Land is required, and as of December 2023, only 74.87 Ha of land was acquired. We understand that the budget for the new line is allocated based on the progress made on land acquisition. Can the TN Govt clarify the status of land acquisition?   - Land acquisition for a new line between Tindivanam and Tiruvannamalai has been ongoing since 2010. Has the Land acquisition been completed?  A similar question arises for other new railway lines where the budgets are cut, and the DMK Government is duty-bound to answer.   The average annual budget outlay to TN was just â‚¹879 crore per year during 2009-14 during the DMK Congress Regime. However, allocations to TN in all streams have increased significantly over the last ten years, and this year's railway budget of â‚¹6362 Crore to TN stands as a testament to this.

ğŸ“¢ HC: Directs to lift attachment from Ford India's bank account; Remands for deciding returns mismatch Ford India Private Limited Vs. Deputy Commissioner W.P.No.16090 of 2024 and W.M.P.Nos.17609 & 17610 of 2024   Facts of the Case â–ªThe case involved Ford India Private Limited challenging an assessment order passed by the Deputy Commissioner. The assessment was based on a mismatch between the company's GSTR-2A and GSTR-9 returns. â–ªThe assessee contended that the assessment order was passed without proper reasoning, as the taxpayer's reply was simply extracted in the order without any explanation or justification for confirming the tax proposal.  Court Judgement â–ª Observations: The Madras High Court observed that the assessment order lacked proper reasoning, noting that the taxpayer's reply was mentioned but not addressed with any specific reasons. â–ª Judgment: The Court set aside the assessment order due to the lack of reasoning and directed that the attachment on Ford India's bank account be lifted. â–ª Outcome: The matter was remanded back to the Deputy Commissioner for reconsideration, with instructions to provide Ford India with a reasonable opportunity for a hearing before making any furtherÂ decisions.

Energy Tariff Rationalization, through cost of service study. All cross subsidies from industrial tariffs must be removed. For instance, the subsidy provided to the fertilizer sector is being charged to the export sector.   3. Access to Capital  4. Immediate Reduction in Interest Rates to 14%  5. Restoration of EFS:    This is essential to document the entire value chain and to facilitate export manufacturing  6. Taxation Issues:    - Exporters are currently subject to a 2% advance tax, while businesses in the same field with domestic sales are paying  1.25%.  7. EDS (0.25%):    - It should be held in abeyance until the surcharge already collected is spent on export development.  8. Sindh Government:    - Charging 1.8% on imports under EFS, which are temporary imports for re-export. These imports should be exempt from taxes, duties, and levies as they are meant for value addition.  9. Punjab Government:    - Charging a 0.20% stamp duty on export-related bills of exchange, a practice not followed by any other province. Update on #Bahrain ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡­  Bahrain new employer and employee taxes:  Employee TaxesÂ  Employee Contributions:  8% for Local workers and 1% for Expat workers.  Social Insurance (GOSI), includes coverage towards medical, retirement and disability. Employee Income Tax Bahrain charges no personal income tax.  Employer TaxesÂ  Employer Payroll Contributions: 16%  In Bahrain, employers must contribute to social insurance as follows: For Bahraini employees: 12% of the gross salary. For expatriate employees: 3% of the gross salary(Which Covers employment injuries, expatriate employees contribute 1% covers unemployment. )  Bahrain New data retention policies:  In Bahrain, data protection and retention policies are governed by the Personal Data Protection Law (PDPL), which came into effect on August 1, 2019. This law regulates how personal data should be collected, processed, stored, and retained. Here are key points regarding data retention under Bahrain's PDPL:  Purpose Limitation: Personal data must be retained only for as long as necessary to fulfill the purposes for which it was collected. Once the purpose is achieved, data should be deleted or anonymized.  Data Minimization: Organizations should ensure that only data necessary for the specified purposes is collected and retained.  Accuracy and Up-to-Date Data: Organizations are required to keep personal data accurate and up-to-date. Any inaccuracies should be corrected or deleted.

ğŸ”¥ğŸ“› HC set aside order rejecting subsequent application on grounds of limitation as initially it was filed before wrong authority  â¡ï¸ The petitioner filed a refund application for accumulated ITC due to an inverted duty tax structure manually in Form GST RFD-01A due to the unavailability of the online refund module.  â¡ï¸ The application was accepted, and an acknowledgment was generated, but the respondent later issued a deficiency memo and show-cause notice, ultimately rejecting the refund.  â¡ï¸ The rejection was based on the claim that the refund application was filed beyond the two-year time limit from the due date of filing returns under Section 39 of the CGST Act.  â¡ï¸ It was held that the petitioner initially filed the refund application within the prescribed two-year limit and the fresh application after the deficiency memo should be treated as a continuation of the original application.  â¡ï¸ The court set aside the order rejecting the refund and restored the matter for fresh consideration.  âœ”ï¸ Gujarat HC - Darshan Processors v. Union of India [R/SPECIAL CIVIL APPLICATION NOS. 2114, 2115, 2116, 2117 & 4111 OF 2021]  #GST #GSTwithBimalJain #a2ztaxcorpllp #GSTUpdate #GSTcaseLaw

ğŸ”¥ğŸ“› Intelligence Officer has jurisdiction to pass assessment orders under GST law: HC  â¡ï¸ The assessee challenged assessment orders passed by the State Tax Officer (Intelligence) for the Assessment Years 2017-18 to 2019-20 after earlier orders were quashed by the High Court.  â¡ï¸ The assessee argued that, as per a circular, the Intelligence Officer should not adjudicate the matter.  â¡ï¸ The court held that there is no restriction under GST law on an Intelligence Officer passing an assessment order.  â¡ï¸ The court observed that the assessee was not prejudiced merely because the order was passed by an officer from the Intelligence Department.  â¡ï¸ The writ petitions were dismissed, but the court granted the assessee liberty to file a statutory appeal within 30 days.  âœ”ï¸ Madras HC - Tvl. CBDT issues clarification in respect of Income-tax clearance certificate (ITCC).   It is being erroneously reported that all Indian citizens must obtain ITCC before leaving the country. This position is factually incorrect.   Vide Finance (No.2) Act, 2024, Black Money (Undisclosed Foreign Income and Assets) and Imposition of Tax Act, 2015 ( the 'Black Money Act')  has been added to the list of Acts u/s 230(1A) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, whereby any resident leaving the country is required to obtain a tax clearance certificate in certain circumstances.   This insertion has been made only to cover the liabilities under the Black Money Act.   For details, pl check the Press Release: https://pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2047104

The Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) has issued a clarification addressing recent misinformation regarding the need for an income-tax clearance certificate (ITCC) for Indian citizens travelling abroad. Contrary to recent reports, all Indian citizens don't need to obtain an ITCC before leaving the country.  This section, originally enacted through the Finance Act, of 2003, pertains to the circumstances under which a tax clearance certificate must be obtained by persons domiciled in India. The recent amendment merely adds references to the Black Money (Undisclosed Foreign Income and Assets) and Imposition of Tax Act, 2015, ensuring that liabilities under this Act are treated similarly to those under the Income-tax Act.  CBDT highlighted that the requirement for an ITCC applies only in specific scenarios. As per the existing provisions and instructions, only individuals involved in serious financial irregularities or those with direct tax arrears exceeding Rs. 10 lakh (not stayed by any authority) need to obtain the ITCC. This regulation has been in place since 2003 and remains unchanged by the recent amendment.  The Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) clarified that an ITCC is required only in specific cases:  Serious Financial Issues: If someone is involved in major financial problems and their presence is needed for investigations.  Large Unpaid Taxes: If a person owes more than Rs. 10 lakh in taxes that are not on hold by any authority.  The notification further added that the process to obtain an ITCC involves recording specific reasons and obtaining approval from the Principal Chief Commissioner of Income or Chief Commissioner of income tax.

CBDT issues clarification in respect of Income-tax clearance certificate (ITCC). (which I already tweeted on 28th July)   It is being erroneously reported that all Indian citizens must obtain ITCC before leaving the country. This position is factually incorrect.    Vide Finance (No.2) Act, 2024, Black Money (Undisclosed Foreign Income and Assets) and Imposition of Tax Act, 2015 ( the 'Black Money Act')  has been added to the list of Acts u/s 230(1A) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, whereby any resident leaving the country is required to obtain a tax clearance certificate in certain circumstances.

#ITR The deadline to verify a submitted income tax return (ITR) is 30 days from the date of filing of the ITR. Data as of August 20, 2024 6pm shows that 31,48,582 ITRs have been submitted but are yet to be verified.   Moreover, data also shows that 2.28 crore ITRs were filed between July 27 and July 31, 2024. So this means that these 2.28 crore ITR filers have to verify their ITR if not done already by August 26 and August 30, 2024. (Read the story to know more about this data analysis)  As per @twinklejain, "If an ITR is not verified within this (the 30 day) period, it is considered invalid. This means that any tax refund claims associated with these ITRs will not be processed, and the taxpayer may have to file the ITR again, resulting in a delay in the tax refund process."  Suresh Surana shares a table showing what are the ITR verifcation deadlines for various dates in July and August 2024 (Read the story to see this)   CA Ashish Niraj shares his insight about the tax law and interprets how this ITR verification deadline of 30 days is counted.  https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/wealth/tax/these-itr-filers-have-only-days-left-to-verify-their-itrs-else-itr-invalid/articleshow/112671297.cms

[4] What's the confusion?ğŸ¤”  There is misinformation spreading due to a misunderstanding of the recent amendmentğŸ‘‡  Some reports incorrectly claim that all Indian citizens must obtain an income-tax clearance certificate (ITCC) before leaving the country  This is incorrectâŒ

[1] Background  Section 230(1A) requires individuals to obtain tax clearance certificate before leaving India, ensuring they've paid all taxes  Finance (No. 2) Act, 2024 added reference to Black Money Act, meaning the certificate also covers undisclosed foreign income/assets

[6] Conclusion  Not all Indian citizens must obtain an income-tax clearance certificate (ITCC) before leaving the countryâœ…  This has been clarified by CBDT in a recent press release.  Link to the press release ğŸ”—ğŸ‘‡ https://pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2047104

Chairman, CBDT, Sh Ravi Agrawal, welcomed Hon'ble FM, Hon'ble MoS(F) and all distinguished guests present.  In his welcome address, he gave an overview of the progress made by the CBDT in recent years & emphasized that the Dept would continue to use technology-driven processes to realize Hon'ble PM's vision of a 'Viksit Bharat.'  He further highlighted the digital transformation of the Department coupled with non-intrusive tax administration, at the same time, achieving a 17.7% growth in direct tax collections in FY 2023-24.   He further emphasized upon the success of the New Tax Regime, broadening the tax base, the success of faceless assessment regime, and the comprehensive review of the Income-tax Act underway for simplification and certainty of taxpayers.  #IncomeTaxDay

CBDT issues clarification in respect of Income-tax clearance certificate (ITCC) Section 230 (1A) of the Income-tax Act, relates to obtaining of a tax clearance certificate, in certain circumstances,by persons domiciled in India. The said provision, as it stands, came on the statute through the Finance Act, 2003 w.e.f. 1.6.2003. The Finance (No.2) Act, 2024 has made only an amendment in Section 230(1A) of the Act, vide which, reference of the Black Money (Undisclosed Foreign Income and Assets) and Imposition of Tax Act, 2015 has been inserted in the said Section. This insertion has been made to also cover the liabilities under the Black Money Act in the same manner as the liabilities under the Income-tax Act,1961 and other Acts dealing with direct taxes for the purpose of Section 230(1A) of the Income-tax Act,1961 #IncomeTax

Hon'ble FM, Smt @nsitharaman, in her keynote address, complimented the versatility of the officers and officials of the Income Tax Department.  Hon'ble FM commended the Department for achieving the highest ever tax collection. Hon'ble FM further commended the success of the faceless assessment and appeals regime.   Hon'ble FM exhorted the Department to be fair & friendly and ensure that there is improved taxpayer experience. The tax notices should be temperate, simple and easy to understand for the taxpayer.   Hon'ble FM underlined the judicious use of power to ensure compliance, not create fear among the taxpayers.   Hon'ble FM also laid emphasis on speedy issue of refunds and following of due process to encourage voluntary compliance.   Hon'ble also underlined transition to principle of nudge in line with Hon'ble PM's vision to make taxation easy, simple and rational leading to widening of tax base.   At the same time, Hon'ble FM  emphasized upon capacity building especially in terms of adopting global best practices in tax administration.    Hon'ble FM expressed her heartfelt gratitude to the honest taxpayers for their contribution in delivering on welfare & development, appreciating the fact that there were 58.57 lakh first-time ITR filers in FY 2024-25. It showcased that India was getting more formalized as an economy and more people are coming forward to voluntarily pay taxes.   Hon'ble FM appreciated the growing trust among taxpayers towards the Department.  #IncomeTaxDay

Outward supply liable to RCM-Disclosure in GST-3B  Taxable value shall be disclosed in 3.1(a) with Taxes as 0 (Since @Infosys_GSTN  Portal does not accept 0, hence we can enter 0.01 in taxes)  Also note that Outward Supplies liable to RCM gets auto-populated in 3.1(a) only from GSTR-1   This supply shall not be reported in 3.1(c) as Exempt supply as this supply is not an Exempted Supply i.e. not exempted via any notification but only the payment of Tax liability has been shifted to Recipient of supply. "Interviewer: Apparently, you love to make sequels for exactly this reason: you can really go for it with the audience because they already know what to expect.  Raimi: For me, sequels have been economical necessities. I made a movie called The Evil Dead, my first low budget horror movie, and I quit college to make it, and that did okay. And then I made a bomb that nobody would release! So the only movie I could possibly make was the sequel to the one that had a little success; so Evil Dead II kind of saved my life. It was the only movie I could make. And then in the case of Spider-Man, I set it up when we were working on the script with our writers to make sure that it had a continuation, so that the next director could pick up story threads. I didn't know I'd be directing it, but I'd set it up for a director with unresolved conflicts. I realized that I really liked the team and the crew, and I wanted to tell that story myself. So it's for different reasons that I make sequels, but it's worked out very well for me."  (Sam Raimi, Emma Robertson, The Talks, 2022)

Ever wonder if budgeting is really worth the hassle? Let's debunk some common myths and show you how budgeting can actually empower you! ğŸ§ğŸ’¡  Myth: Budgeting ties you down, leaving no room for flexibility ğŸš«   Truth: A budget actually gives you more control over your money, allowing you to spend on what truly matters. It's about prioritising, not restricting. You can still enjoy life; you just do it smarter!  Myth: Creating and maintaining a budget takes too much time and effort â³   Truth: With today's tools and apps, budgeting can be done in minutes. Plus, the time you invest now saves you countless hours (and headaches) later. A little planning goes a long way!  Myth: Budgeting is only necessary if you have a lot of money to manage ğŸ’¸   Truth: Budgeting is essential no matter your income level. In fact, it's even more critical when your income is limited as it helps you make the most of what you have.  Myth: Sticking to a budget means you have to sacrifice all the fun things in life ğŸ˜’   Truth: Budgeting is about balance. By planning for entertainment and leisure, you can enjoy guilt-free spending, knowing it won't derail your financial goals.  Myth: I've tried budgeting, but it just doesn't seem to work for me ğŸ™…â€â™‚ï¸   Truth: Budgeting isn't one-size-fits-all. If one method doesn't work, try another one. Whether it's the 50/30/20 rule, zero-based budgeting, or using apps to automate your savings, there's a method out there for you too. Don't give up.  Need a hand with budgeting? PUNTLAND MINISTER OF FINANCE FINALLY CONFIRMS RECEIPT OF ALL BILLED BUDGET SUPPORT FUNDS FROM THE WORLD BANK  After much politicized back and forth blame game and heated fingerpointing between Puntland State House and the Federal Government of Somalia Ministry of Finance, where the FGS shared details of over $6 million in budget support funds transfered to Puntland, but Puntland State House denying receipt of any funds either directly from the World Bank or through the Central Bank of Somalia, Radio Daljir has finally reached out to Puntland Minister of Finance Mr. Mohamed Farah Mohamoud.  Minister Farah tells Radio Daljir that "irrespective of what has been exchanged over social media, I can without hesitation confirm to you that Puntland Ministry of Finance has received all budget support funds requested from the World Bank and was subsequently transferred through the Central Bank of Somalia and into Puntland Treasury. There is nothing in arrears. All funds have been billed, transferred, and received."  On budget support funds often alleged by Puntland to be delayed by Somalia's Ministry of Finance, Radio Daljir has reached out to an anonymous high-ranking MP in the FGS Parliament and the MP responded, "Budget support funds are in the Federal Budget passed by the Parliament, and no one, I repeat no one, has the ability to delay or deny those funds from Somalia's Federal Member States."  > Daljir Media

Phantom income refers to income reported on paper but not actually received. This often arises from unrealised gains or accrued income, creating a tax liability on income that hasn't been realised.  What you need to know:  â–«ï¸Income is recorded but not physically received. â–«ï¸It leads to tax burdens based on paper gains. â–«ï¸It can affect cash flow and financial stability. â–«ï¸The government is tightening regulations to address this issue.  For businesses and investors, understanding and managing phantom income is crucial. Consulting with a financial advisor can help navigate these complexities and avoid unexpected tax liabilities.  #taxation #taxability #goalteller

The Direct Tax Code (DTC) is a proposed framework in India aimed at reforming the direct taxation system, which includes taxes directly paid to the government by individuals and corporations, such as income tax and corporate tax. (1/n)
Key Features of the DTC:Simplification of Tax Laws: The DTC sought to replace the complex and often ambiguous Income Tax Act of 1961 with a simpler, more straightforward set of rules. (3/n)

Widening the Tax Base: One of the objectives was to broaden the tax base by reducing exemptions and deductions that are often used to lower taxable income. A broader tax base ensures that more people contribute to the tax system, increasing government revenue. (5/n)

#ITR Data shows that 1,87,47,804 (about 1.87 crore) income tax returns (ITRs) are yet to be processed out of 7,13,00,901 verified ITRs. Does this mean that these unprocessed ITRs are likely to be picked for scrutiny? Probably not.   As per Ankit Jain â€‹"It's important to note that the selection of returns for scrutiny is handled independently by the tax authorities and is unrelated to the processing of tax returns. The processing stage primarily checks for mathematical accuracy and verifies claims for tax credits. Scrutiny notices are issued later when the tax authorities identify ITRs that require further examination or additional information"  As per Swapnil Patni â€‹"I would say, that while there is a slight chance, it's more likely that the delay is due to procedural reasons rather than scrutiny. There is a possibility, but it's not necessarily the case that all unprocessed ITRs are picked for scrutiny. If your ITR were selected for scrutiny, you would typically receive a notice or communication from the Income Tax Department outlining the reason and required actions. Additionally, it's important to note that even if your ITR is processed without any demand, it can still be selected for scrutiny later."   "While it's possible that a portion of the unprocessed ITRs may be flagged for scrutiny, this is unlikely to be the primary reason for the delay in processing of such a large percentage of filings," says Sandeep Agrawal  With inputs from Abhishek Soni  https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/wealth/tax/26-itrs-yet-to-be-processed-after-22-days-of-the-deadline-will-your-itr-come-under-scrutiny/articleshow/112728081.cms

Globally, China dominates EV markets, backed by $230.9 billion in government support. Even with reduced subsidies, EV sales remain strong there. This suggests that subsidies are crucial for market maturity and behavioral changeâ€”a lesson for India.  +

Subsidies, like FAME I & II, played a critical role in boosting EV adoption. Yet, confusing rules and misuse of funds under FAME II slowed progress, leading to its halt. The newly introduced Electric Mobility Promotion Scheme (EMPS) aims to revive this momentum.  +

While EVs offer long-term savings in fuel and maintenance, their upfront costs remain high. India still needs subsidies to make EV ownership more appealing. Removing these prematurely risks stalling adoption, a critical factor as the market is still maturing.

CBDT forms committee to review I-T Act, 'sunset' clauses to be eliminated  An internal committee of the Income Tax Department will review the 1961 direct tax law to eliminate redundant clauses as well as adopt best global practices to simplify it for taxpayers for better compliance, CBDT chief Ravi Agrawal has said.  The panel, comprising income tax (IT) officials from across the country, has started working to identify areas of improvement in the Income Tax Act, 1961, he said and added that the exercise is being conducted under a central government-mandated comprehensive review of the law.  Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) chairman Agrawal said the committee is looking at the best global practices that can be adopted as well as cutting redundancies in the existing law and finding those clauses that have reached their sunset, and hence, can be eliminated.  "An internal committee of competent officers of the department from all across the country has been formed. They have started working to identify areas of improvement. This is a work in progress...," he told PTI on Wednesday during an event here to mark 165 years of income tax in India.  He said the committee is looking at the "problem statement" given to it in the recent Budget. It is trying to find the "best way forward" in giving the country a new direct tax law, Agrawal said.  During the event, the CBDT chief assured Union Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman that the work of reviewing the Act will be done within the stipulated time-frame of six months as announced by her in the Budget presented last month.  The minister, during the Wednesday event, asked the I-T department to use simple language in its notices and communications with taxpayers so that they are able to understand these quickly without getting intimidated.  Agrawal said this factor is also a part of the I-T law review. The committee is trying to make tax communication simple and easy to understand to encourage compliance of rules by taxpayers, he said. The Income Tax Act, 1961, started its journey in 1922. It contains 298 sections and 23 chapters and other provisions in its current form of 1961.  Sitharaman, while presenting the 2024-25 Union Budget, had announced a "comprehensive" review of the Income Tax Act.  The purpose is to make the Act concise, lucid, easy to read and understand.  This will reduce disputes and litigation, thereby providing tax certainty to the taxpayers. It will also bring down the demand embroiled in litigation. It is proposed to be completed in six months, she had said.  Agrawal also said the CBDT will "put more officers" within the next 10-15 days to "expeditiously" clear the "substantial" number of appeals pending at the Income Tax Department level.  Source from: https://www.business-standard.com/economy/news/cbdt-forms-committee-to-review-i-t-act-sunset-clauses-to-be-eliminated-124082200538_1.html

Rajasthan high court notices to Centre on new clause the Income Tax Act  In a writ petition filed by the Garment Exporters Association of Rajasthan challenging the constitutional validity of a new clause under section 43B(h) of the Income Tax Act, a Rajasthan high court division bench comprising Justices Pankaj Bhandari and Praveer Bhatnagar has issued notices to the Centre and the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT).  The court has instructed the respondents to provide reasons why a stay should not be granted on the enforcement of this provision, which relates to payments made to micro and small enterprises (MSEs), for the duration of the petition's pendency. Next hearing in the case is scheduled for Sept 20.  The petitioners contended that the Act's section 43B(h) places significant financial burden on businesses, especially those in export sector, as it imposes strict payment timelines for buyers, while export payments often take longer to process. Moreover, there is already a penalty in the form of high interest payments on delayed payments and disallowance of such interest in computing income. "Therefore, treating purchase price as income would be highly arbitrary and discretionary," the petitioner contended.
